Past Layouts

I wanted to start a log of the past iterations of the site, so I can look back on all the terrible code I've written good memories I‚Äôve made!

üéÉ Version 3: 3-column throwback | October 2023 - current

I coded this new layout over two days, listening to Pain Hasn‚Äôt Hit Me by The Crane almost exclusively. It reminded me of listening to Burning by The Whitest Boy Alive in high school, browsing tumblrs of girls who were definitely cooler than me. Fitting with that nostalgia, I wanted to create a desktop layout that I don‚Äôt see often anymore: the classic ‚Äúholy grail‚Äù 3-column layout. I immediately went to Matthew James Taylor‚Äôs website as it offers the bare bones code for literally any layout you could possibly want. As a bonus, they‚Äôre all responsive for mobile, and he offers many different ways to approach the layouts using CSS grid, flex, or whatever you‚Äôre comfortable with. There are so many sites on Neocities that could be mobile-friendly, and this is such an easy way to go about that. I hope more folks learn from this incredible resource.

Once I had the code for my site structure, I wanted to add a theme switcher for Halloween. This is done easily just by switching out whatever you want to customize in your main CSS file by swapping in variables and having those defined in separate style sheets that some JS can point to. I followed this very easy tutorial that provided all the code snippets needed, then I got busy, committing as many CSS crimes as I wanted. The entire effort took about two days, but the majority of that was spent tweaking the CSS to figure out fun combinations that worked well together and then leaving it alone for a while so I could view it with fresh eyes. One of the really helpful resources I used to develop cohesive color schemes for each layout was colorffy‚Äôs CSS / SCSS¬†color variables¬†generator. You just specify a HEX code for a color you like, and it spits out a family of related shades, which you can then evaluate to ensure you‚Äôve got the right contrast ratios for your site.

  • pixel font used in the purple theme
  • typewriter font used in the halloween theme
  • my new guestbook is powered by code from virtualobserver with a h/t to Frills for pointing me their way and creating moderation capabilities
  • recreated my original layout from Fool Lovers using just a couple lines of code thanks to border-image css - November 08, 2023

üöÄ Version 2: Lost in Space! | March 2023 - October 2023

With this layout, I simplified the elements of my first layout using the body styling from Pale‚Äôs gorgeous Glassy layout. I‚Äôve been totally on a space kick, playing Starforged, reading Leviathan Wakes by James S. A. Corey, and watching The Expanse, which is based on that book. I think that probably explains why I went with the space background. It‚Äôs hard to find something dark, but not too boring.

  • Added this page (Mar ‚Äò23), TTRPG section (Mar ‚Äò23), Health section (May ‚Äò23), reworked my toybox into a semi-shrine (Aug ‚Äò23), tamagotchi shrine (Aug ‚Äò23)
  • High-contrast text colors for better accessibility
  • Mariela Monsalv - creator of my body font (Asul)
  • Directory of open source fonts by womxn - how I found Asul

üéÄ Version 1: Lace Letters | Oct 2022 - March 2023

This layout was adapted from a template by Fool Lovers. They provided the lace header, lacy content container graphics and code, url hover sparkles, favicon, and bouncing sakura divider. I will always be extremely fond of this layout since it was the first one I tweaked to my liking to launch Lost Letters on Neocities. A lot of folks enjoyed the gorgeous pixel art based on the guestbook entries from that time.

  • Designed my beloved dropdown menu bar
  • Major content sections: q*bee shrine, confessions, stationery
  • Hewett Tsoi - creator of my pixel header font (Alagard)

Technical Notes

My static site is generated by Jekyll. I am hosted by Neocities. I push my code from my computer to Neocities with Bret Comnes‚Äô deploy-to-neocities workflow, and I followed this guide to set that up. For the non-technical, Jekyll-curious, I wrote out every single step I took to set up Jekyll for this site as a complete beginner, including creating a Github account.

My blog posts on web dev include all the sources I found and used while working on technical aspects of this site and creating my ideal developer environment. I felt like it was most useful to attribute those in context, so please refer to individual posts for those sources.

Assets

  • Index pixels that change per theme are by King Lulu Deer on DeviantArt
  • Index stamps: stars | purple | mail | spoopy
  • Pokyaron - 88x31 button base
  • Fool Lovers - sakura divider, orange bats background
  • pixel-soup & lost-sozai - in-line emoticons
  • Flyff - cursor
  • envelope css
  • sakura stamp
  • GifCities - Guestbook gif
  • Tamagotchi, neopets badges from web.badges.world
  • Chaotic good and pansexual badges by Lou (Elfwink)
  • Created the trans rights, vegan always, and union member badges with this button maker tool
